newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Cetes rate shrugs FOMC hike to end down.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Cetes rate shrugs FOMC hike to end down.

text.p: Mexican overnight Cetes rates fended off an expected increase in U.S. interest rates to close down 60 basis points at 21.40 percent on Tuesday.
"The FOMC hike was already discounted. The market it took it well, as the peso reacted well," a trader said, adding that Mexican interest rates were still expensive despite higher U.S. rates.
The U.S. Federal Open Market Committee announced in late trade it had decided to raise the federal funds rate by 25 basis points to 5.50 percent.
"The peso firmed up very well on Monday and was strong today. I think we may see firm rates," another dealer said.
Benchmark 48-hour peso contracts ended 0.3 of a centavo softer at 7.8930/7.8950 per dollar, which traders said was due to pre-weekend swap deals rather than the decision to raise U.S. interest rates.
Overnight rates on Cetes reached a high of 21.75 percent during the session, but were mostly stable.
"There was little dealing. Many bought term paper last week and others just waited for the FOMC decision," a dealer said.
Dealers said turnover was light due to forthcoming Easter holidays, which will be celebrated on March 27 and 28.
Overnight rates on bank paper meanwhile closed down 25 basis points at 22.75 percent.
Banco de Mexico drained 1.966 billion pesos from the market through four auctions which it assigned at rates of between 22.70 and 22.91 percent.
Liquidity of 4.920 billion pesos was scheduled to return to the system on Wednesday from prior central bank participation.
